description: From Middle English night-mare, from Old English *nihtmare, equivalent to night +‎ mare (“evil spirit believed to afflict a sleeping person”). Cognate with Scots nichtmare and nichtmeer, Dutch nachtmerrie, Middle Low German nachtmār, German Nachtmahr.

entries.meaning: (now rare) A demon or monster, thought to plague people while they slept and cause a feeling of suffocation and terror during sleep. [from 14th c.]
examples: I started, hourly, from dreams of unutterable fear, to find the hot breath of the thing upon my face, and its vast weight—an incarnate Night-Mare that I had no power to shake off—incumbent eternally upon my heart!

entries.meaning: (now chiefly historical) A feeling of extreme anxiety or suffocation experienced during sleep; Sleep paralysis. [from 16th c.]
examples: Had been afflicted in the night with that strange complaint called the nightmare.

entries.meaning: A very bad or frightening dream. [from 19th c.]
examples: I had a nightmare that I tried to run but could neither move nor breathe.

entries.meaning: (figuratively) Any bad, miserable, difficult or terrifying situation or experience that arouses anxiety, terror, agony or great displeasure. [from 20th c.]
examples: Cleaning up after identity theft can be a nightmare of phone calls and letters.

verbs.description: nightmare (third-person singular simple present nightmares, present participle nightmaring, simple past and past participle nightmared)
